name: Bernese Mountain Dog
description: Bernese Mountain Dogs are gentle giants with unfortunately high rates of cancer and a short lifespan. Cancer is the leading cause of death, affecting nearly half of all Berners. Combined with joint issues and bloat risk, pet insurance is essential for this beloved breed.

faqs.question: Why do Bernese Mountain Dogs have such a short lifespan?
faqs.answer: Cancer, particularly histiocytic sarcoma, affects Berners at alarming rates. Nearly 50% die from cancer, often before age 8. This genetic predisposition significantly shortens their lifespan compared to other large breeds.

faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for a Bernese Mountain Dog?
faqs.answer: Absolutely essential. With cancer rates near 50% and high orthopedic issues, most Berners will face major medical expenses. A single cancer treatment can exceed $15,000. Insurance is mandatory for this breed.

faqs.question: What annual limit do I need?
faqs.answer: We recommend unlimited coverage. Cancer treatment plus joint surgery could easily exceed $20,000 in a single year. Policies with $10,000 annual limits are inadequate for this breed.

faqs.question: When should I insure my Berner?
faqs.answer: Immediately as a puppy. Joint issues can develop during rapid growth (4-12 months), and cancer can strike at any age. Early insurance ensures maximum coverage for this high-risk breed.

faqs.question: Should I consider a prophylactic gastropexy?
faqs.answer: Yes, strongly consider having your Berner's stomach tacked during spay/neuter surgery. This prevents bloat, which is life-threatening and expensive to treat. Some insurance covers this preventive procedure.
